content.webTitle: Sunglasses that are stylish and offer sun protection? It’s easier than you think

fields.headline: Sunglasses that are stylish and offer sun protection? It’s easier than you think
fields.bodyText: Courtney Hancock spends copious amounts of time outdoors and in the water, and is well aware of the importance of protecting her eyes from the sun’s harmful UV rays. So much so that she’s fronting OPSM’s Guard Your Eyes campaign alongside Bondi Rescue’s Trent “Maxi” Maxwell this summer. Having grown up in the coastal town of Sawtell in New South Wales and now living on the Gold Coast in Queensland, Courtney has never been far from the beach. “I’m in the sun a lot,” she says. “Being in Queensland it’s quite hot and the sun’s always shining bright. I’m in the pool at 5am until 7am, then I’ll run for an hour or so, then again in the afternoon.” When your profession involves being outdoors all day, sun protection is crucial, and this summer Courtney is on the hunt for the perfect prescription sunglasses. When function meets form Courtney admits that ticking the style box when it comes to eyewear is “definitely high up” on her agenda, but because she has a pterygium (an eye condition that can affect those who spend a significant amount of time in the sun) in her left eye, any sunglasses she chooses also have to offer maximum protection. This is something with which Peter Murphy, director of eyecare and community at Luxottica Australia and New Zealand, agrees. “Sunglasses are going to give you 100% UV cut-out - that’s provided you purchase sunglasses that comply with the Australian standards,” he says. “The other aspect of sunglasses is that they will provide protection not just for your eyes, but the sensitive skin and tissue around the eyes. We tend to think of slip, slop, slap and putting sunscreen on our face, but it’s quite difficult to put sunscreen near your eyes, and that particular part of the face is quite sensitive. This is where sunglasses can help.” To ensure she picks the right prescription sunglasses, Courtney first decides to have her eyes checked. “It’s a good reminder that your eyes aren’t always going to be this young, so you have to look after them,” she says. “The optometrist said that I’ve done a really great job looking after my pterygium, and it’s not affecting anything at the moment, and [having prescription sunglasses] is also something that is going to really help it not get any worse.” Murphy recommends having your eyes tested every two years, or annually if you’re over 40. The test is important for checking the health of your eyes and detecting conditions such as glaucoma or macular degeneration, but also to ensure your prescription is up to date. Framing up the options Courtney’s wish list included finding a pair of sunglasses for everyday wear, one for training and another “for fashion” to cover every facet of her lifestyle. “Finding what colour is going to suit me, and what style, mixing that all together, is probably something that I’ve been, just, ‘Oh, I like that’, and I’ll just grab those, instead of really going, ‘OK, what’s the best for me?’ “For example, the best for me is having [frames that are] wrapped around the sides, so the sun can’t peer in. I just never realised there were so many things that I really needed [when it comes to sunglasses].” Courtney eventually settled on a sturdy pair of all-rounder Ray-Ban Wayfarers for daily use, a pair of wraparound Oakleys for when she’s running and paddling (these, Murphy says, will provide the best protection from glare and UV light), and fashionable Prada sunglasses “for lunch with the girls”. In the process she learned the value of polarised lenses, which are worth considering if you want to get the most from a pair of sunglasses. Murphy says: “They will give you protection from reflected glare, in particular if you’re on the water, if you’re sailing or down on the beach, even while driving or if you’re on a ski slope. “The important thing is for sunglasses to give you good coverage so that UV light is not coming in, from the side. This is where an optical dispenser will certainly look at a person’s face and make sure that the frame is fitting well.” The verdict Courtney is pleased with the results. “I’ve got that balance now, where I love my sunglasses, and I know they’re good for me,” she says. Find the perfect shades this summer at OPSM.
